title: 113_s2383
content: The "Certify It Act of 2014" is a study on the impact on small business jobs. The "Certify It Act of 2014" requires the Comptroller General of the United States to conduct a study on the impact of the Affordable Care Act on small businesses, including the effects on health insurance costs and job losses. The Comptroller General of the United States will submit a report to Congress on the study conducted on the impact of the Affordable Care Act on small businesses. The appropriate committees of Congress include the Committee on Ways and Means, the Committee on Education and the Workforce, the Committee on Energy and Commerce, and the Small Business Committee of the House of Representatives, as well as the Committee on Finance, the Committee on Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions, and the Small Business and Entrepreneurship Committee of the Senate. The Affordable Care Act refers to specific legislation, while a small business is defined as an employer with 250 or fewer employees. SEC. 3. STUDY ON IMPACT ON SMALL BUSINESS HEALTH INSURANCE. The Office of the Actuary, Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services, will conduct a study on the impact of the Affordable Care Act on small group health insurance costs, including requirements and benefits such as community rating, minimum actuarial value, essential health benefits, and cost-sharing. The Office of the Actuary will study the impact of the Affordable Care Act on small group health insurance costs, including cost-sharing requirements, prohibitions on limits, preventive services, dependent coverage extension, new taxes, and fees. The Office of the Actuary will study the impact of the Affordable Care Act on small group health insurance costs, including new taxes, fees, and assessments. A report will be submitted to Congress for review. The appropriate committees include the Committee on Ways and Means, the Committee on Education and the Workforce, the Committee on Energy and Commerce, and the Small Business Committee. The Office of the Actuary will study the impact of the Affordable Care Act on small group health insurance costs, including new taxes, fees, and assessments. A report will be submitted to Congress for review by relevant committees in the House of Representatives and the Senate. The Affordable Care Act allows for a one-year delay in the employer mandate if it causes net employment loss among small businesses or increases small group health insurance costs. If a report by the Comptroller General or the Office of the Actuary shows these impacts, section 4980H of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 will not apply for a year. If no report is submitted on time, the mandate will not apply the following year.
